I'm not actually testing servlets or JSPs or HTTP request/response. I'm
trying to test objects that require data accessing services that run on our
server. Ideally I could run my tests from a JSPTestRunner and be able to use
the TestSuite/TestCase hierarchy and success/failure reporting of JUnit.

It looks like J2EEUnit might do the trick (from a quick look at their site).

-----Original Message-----
From: Erik Meade [mailto:emeade@...]
Sent: Wednesday, March 14, 2001 3:21 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] how to setup tests in a server environment?


Andy,

Oh yeah... what all do you want to do?

There are some extensions on the "Extensions" page of junit.org.  The ones
you probably want to look at first are J2EEUnit, JUnitEE, and HttpUnit.

--
Erik Meade             emeade@...
Senior Consultant      Object Mentor, Inc.
http://www.junit.org <http://www.junit.org/>

-----Original Message-----
From: Andy Kriger [mailto:akriger@...]
Sent: Wednesday, March 14, 2001 12:02 PM
To: JUnit (E-mail)
Subject: [junit] how to setup tests in a server environment?



I would like to use JUnit to run tests in our current dev environement but
I'm not sure how to proceed. We use WebLogic as our web/JSP server. On this
server we are running a set of WebLogic services that retrieve data from our
databases. I want to test the objects that interact with those services.
This means I have to have create the objects within the WebLogic context (as
servlets or in JSP files).

Is there a way to take advantage of JUnit's testing framework (including the
assertions, logging of problems and the display of results) from within a
servlet? Has anyone written a TestCase/TestSuite servlet?

Andy Kriger
